instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7010: What is D7010? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year retina model macbook pros, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.C7125: What is C7125? Capacitor between CHGR_BOOT and CHGR_PHASE important for bootstrapping creation of PPBUS_G3H on 2013-2015 macbook pros.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.CHGR_PHASE: What is CHGR_PHASE? CHGR_PHASE is charger voltage chopped up into individual slices prior to smoothing where it becomes PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CONN: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CONN? This is the where the battery’s power rail connects to the motherboard. .
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_R: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_R? This is a power rail between the battery and a current sense resistor before the battery power feeds current to the rest of the machine. .
definitions.D7105: What is D7105? Diodes between PPDCIN_G3H charger voltage and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, when CHGR_DCIN Is low(less than charger voltage) and PPBUS_G3H is missing this is a critical point to troubleshoot.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2014 - NO DISPLAY
threads.message:
Hello dear friends!
I bought Macbook Pro 2014 from ebay that was dead, there was missing <DIODE>D7010</DIODE> and there was no green light on charger, after fixing that there is no chime i'm not sure is sound working or not, also there is a short circuit on battery rail, but that is also not my main concern....

There is no display, I have output on HDMI out and device is working properly (without sound and battery) but screen doesn't turn on.
I have measured 52 V on
[TABLE]
[TR]
[TD]1[/TD]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>[/TD]
[/TR]
[/TABLE]

5V on
[TABLE]
[TR]
[TD]28[/TD]
[TD]<SIGNAL>PP5VR3V3_SW_LCD</SIGNAL>[/TD]
[/TR]
[/TABLE]

I will measure resistance and voltage drop on every pin of J8300 today.
I replaced this - <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> <CHIP>U8330</CHIP> <CHIP>U8300</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C8352</CAPACITOR>.
Any advice where should I look next?
Also can you replace PCH with just hot air station or you need BGA station?

Thanks in advance.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2014 - NO DISPLAY
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

52V on backlight output, denotes open circuit to the LEDs strip.
Check J8300 first and test with known good compatible LCD assembly.

Do not try to change a PCH without proper equipment (BGA rework station).
I hope you don't want to change it on this board.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2014 - NO DISPLAY
threads.message:
Hi,


motherboard works fine on hdmi output, so I suppose that PCH is fine.
Under the microscope I saw that screen connector is damaged, in diode mode while testing connector I measured some 0.09 OHM-s that I'm worry about, how to test the screen, do you know what should be the measurement on screen connector pins on diode mode (red on ground ?) or in ohms?
I'm just starting so I have parts for few older MacBooks. 
LP133WQ1 SJ E1 DCN441406G1FF0H0 LGD 133DA51903DJF 913B are the numbers on the screen.

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2014 - NO DISPLAY
threads.message:
"in diode mode while testing connector I measured some 0.09 OHM-s"
Where did you note such low values?
Switch to ohm scale, instead of diode mode, for very low resistance.

Replace LCD connector, if looks bad.
It could be the culprit and nothing else damaged.

threads.message:
Tomorrow I will buy new cable, and I will replace J8300 before testing new cable, I will let you know what happens!
I got sound working so only problem will be short in battery circuit if screen is working.

Thank you so much this is best forum ever, fast reply with good advices so awesome.

If I will have troubles detecting short in battery circuit I will let you know.
Any known problems when battery shorts the mobo?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2014 - NO DISPLAY
threads.message:
Be sure R/<CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> are good, or <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> will burn again.

Use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads, instead of power button; for testing purpose.

threads.message: 18V unstable, it drops from 18V to 5V and goes back to 18V again withouth battery, with battery is max 9V and drops to 5V, blinking green light on charger was device turning on/of rapidly, <TRANSISTOR>Q7155</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: MacBook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 2014 - NO DISPLAY
threads.message:
If you get 18V at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> is shorted again.

You've said the board worked without battery.
That is not possible with fluctuation 5-18V.
Change <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> at same time.
Be sure to get good solders and check traces continuity.
Just in case, change <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR>; it can't be checked in diode mode.

Check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
